channel.title: SevenAtSevenPolitics
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from SevenAtSevenPolitics, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: WATCH: Dixville Notch splits presidential vote 3-3 in first Election Day vote
item.description: In a presidential election that couldn't be closer, it seemed fitting that the first votes cast on Election Day were evenly split, with three for Dona...

item.title: From Darwin to Wall Street: A Rebuttal
item.description: The problem within finance is its philosophical core; that is, the worldview upon which our analytical frameworks are based.

item.title: Meta’s military push is as much about the battle for open-source AI as it is about actual battles
item.description: Meta makes its model available to the U.S. military with a pitch that's largely about defending its "open source AI" framing.

item.title: Wall Street’s Latest Flood: Private Credit
item.description: Private credit is a treacherous swamp full of opportunists. Is your consultant capable of defying the formidable odds of success?

item.title: It’s Time to Reclaim the West from Federal Control
item.description: For most of the Western United States, an unelected federal bureaucrat is the only sheriff in town.

item.title: Only the Fed Can Create Inflation
item.description: Inflation is a monetary phenomenon, not a fiscal phenomenon.

item.title: N.Y. Republican introduces 'Peanut's Law' after pet squirrel's killing

item.title: From Tweets to Trades: The Risks of Social Media in Investing
item.description: Are you able to step outside the confines of social media echo chambers to make informed investment decisions?

item.title: Pennsylvania county extends voting hours after 'software issue' with scanning ballots
item.description: Polls in a key Pennsylvania county will be open for an additional two hours Tuesday following a malfunction with ballot scanners.

item.title: The United States Does Not Have One National Presidential Election
item.description: The American media could do the nation a tremendous public service on Election Day by repeating ad nauseam this simple civic fact.

item.title: Princeton’s Inane Guide for Teaching during the Election
item.description: You can forget about substantive lectures or rigorous debates.

item.title: Ilhan Omar’s GOP Opponent Counters Incumbent’s ‘Victim Card’
item.description: Dalia al-Aqidi’s political presence is an important reminder of the diversity of American Muslim views.

item.title: Bernard Marcus, a billionaire behind Home Depot, dies at 95
item.description: Marcus served 19 years as Home Depot’s first chief executive officer and was chairman of the board from 1978 until his retirement in 2002.

item.title: Republican Poll Watchers Blocked From Duty In Multiple Pennsylvania Counties
item.description: Republican poll observers were also turned away in at least eight counties.

item.title: Voting on Election Day: Here's when polls close for all 50 states
item.description: Polls cross the country will remain open until at least the early evening local time as Americans cast their ballots on Election Day.

item.title: Looking to run errands on Election Day? These places are open for business
item.description: People out and about on Tuesday's Election Day can make their usual stops for errands. Post offices, banks and most stores are open.

item.title: Ballot Scanners Stop Working In Deep Red PA County, Cause ‘Unacceptable’ Delays
item.description: A software malfunction was preventing voters from scanning their ballots.

item.title: Watch For Democrats Trying To Tilt North Carolina Blue With Overseas Ballots After Election Day
item.description: Overseas voters can have their ballot counted up to nine days after the election, and are not beholden to serious security measures.

item.title: Walz Claims Military Record ‘Speaks For Itself,’ But The Army Still Won’t Release It
item.description: The Federalist asked for Tim Walz's military records in August. By election day, the Army still has not approved their release.

item.title: Gary Gensler’s time as SEC chair may be coming to an end— who will replace him and what does it mean for crypto?
item.description: The crypto industry spent millions of dollars this year to ensure that the SEC chair is replaced.

item.title: Dixville Notch, New Hampshire vote results are in – and point to a very long day
item.description: Election Day begins with midnight voting in this tiny town.
